image.altText: An older man wearing a navy blue polo shirt leans against a pillar outside his home wearing sunglasses with his arms folded.

items.synopsis: As former Qantas workers celebrate their historic victory over the airline in the High Court, an industrial relations lawyer says any compensation bill or financial penalty won't affect Qantas' bottom line — or stop them from outsourcing jobs in the future.

title.children: After being sacked, Don took Qantas to court and won. But experts say the airline could outsource jobs again

image.altText: Emergency services deal with a car on fire in Penrose

items.synopsis: More and more drivers are opting for electronic vehicles over conventional cars. After two unrelated battery fires in Sydney in a week, experts say combustions are still rare.

title.children: Two electric vehicles caught fire in NSW this week. Here's what experts say you should know

image.altText: Greyhound racing

items.synopsis: A Chinese dog buyer has lifted the lid on the extraordinary world of exporting Australian racing greyhounds to China, where their offspring are used to grow the country’s illegal gambling industry.

title.children: Turf wars, debt collection, sabotage: Inside the international operation to ship Australian greyhounds to China

image.altText: Back of a persons head in university graduation.

items.synopsis: Students detail consistent mishandling of sexual violence complaints as part of the biggest review of the university sector in years.

title.children: University students tell major review how the sector can better protect students from sexual violence

image.altText: A man fills his car with petrol.

items.synopsis: Surging fuel prices reignite fears about inflation as production cuts by a global oil cartel heap yet more pain on consumers at service station forecourts.

title.children: Fuel prices to stay above $2 a litre 'for longer' as consumers face fresh inflation fears

image.altText: Houses under construction in the background with building materials in the foreground

items.synopsis: Given the demand for housing across the nation, it seems a paradox that homebuilders are collapsing, but that's been the case in SA in recent months.

title.children: It's been called a 'profitless boom' — why are builders collapsing despite huge demand for homes?

image.altText: Robyn Tremble holding a photo of her son

items.synopsis: Robert Tremble endured six months of suffering after being released from Caboolture Hospital with injuries that would result in his deterioration and eventual death.

title.children: Robyn's son left hospital with three unexplained spinal fractures. Police gave up investigating when he died months later

image.altText: Hand cradling a cup of coffee

items.synopsis: How does caffeine work in your body, how much can you have and is there a best time of the day to drink it? We explore the science behind your morning brew.

title.children: Drinking your morning coffee right now? Here's how to get the most out of it

image.altText: A man fishing on the rocks.

items.synopsis: Barbados has been called the "first slave society". Now it's becoming a global leader in the fight for compensation over the horrors of slavery.

title.children: Can this tiny Caribbean nation make former colonial masters pay for slavery?

image.altText: A town is seen from above, several buildings are destroyed, the landscape is covered in dust

items.synopsis: In the days since a deadly earthquake rippled through Morocco's High Atlas Mountain, devastating stories of loss have emerged. Seismic data and satellite imagery show the sheer scale of this destruction.

title.children: The sheer scale of Morocco's once-in-a-century quake can only be understood from above

image.altText: A burnt out plastic box on the side of a brick wall outside.

items.synopsis: A spike in fires caused by DC isolators has alarmed the NT's workplace safety watchdog, as figures show most other jurisdictions are also recording fires from the devices.

title.children: 'Sparks of fire' from a faulty solar panel component damaged Rose's home. Her story is increasingly common

image.altText: Composite image of close up profile shots of Vanessa Hudson and Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Forced to "acknowledge and accept" the High Court's decision, Qantas has now run out of options in defending its high-stakes pandemic strategy of outsourcing staff for "lawful commercial reasons", writes Peter Ryan.

title.children: The three humiliating words that underscore the enormity of Qantas' High Court loss

image.altText: Tasmania Police vehicles.

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian man who tried to kill his wife and two young children, then attacked his father-in-law when he tried to save them, is sentenced to at least 11 years in prison.

title.children: Man who drove across state to reach wife, children then attempted to murder them to spend at least 11 years in jail

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie and a face mask

items.synopsis: The woman who cannot be identified says she was groomed by the convicted murderer while she was a student in the 1980s.

title.children: 'Ought to have known': former student of killer Chris Dawson sues state

image.altText: A cruiseship sits in the water with snow-capped mountains in the background

items.synopsis: A fishing trawler's attempt to free a luxury cruise ship that ran aground two days ago in a remote part of Greenland has failed, leaving the vessel and the 206 people on board still stranded.

title.children: Fishing trawler fails to free luxury cruise ship grounded in Greenland

image.altText: A flooded street with boats and rescue vehicles and people

items.synopsis: New analysis of Australia's costliest natural disasters shows the danger posed by cyclones and flooding to the nation's east coast.

title.children: Costly cyclone disaster looms for Australia’s east coast

image.altText: Kim and Putin shaking hands

items.synopsis: With few allies left on the world stage, the meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and North Korean President Kim Jong Un is seen by observers as a sign of just how far Russia has fallen.

title.children: 'Russia would not be doing this if it had other options': Putin's desperate meeting with Kim Jong Un

image.altText: A white cat wearing a patterned bandana around its neck, licking its lips

items.synopsis: Cats fed vegan diets tended to be healthier than their meat-fed counterparts, according to a new study. But, experts warn, the evidence for vegan kitties is not that clear-cut.

title.children: A new study says cats fed vegan food are healthier than meat-eaters. So why do vets urge caution?

image.altText: Sydney Opera House lit up in Green and Gold

items.synopsis: The Opera House remained bare in May for the coronation of King Charles III, due to a $75,000 price tag, but emails show the true cost was much lower.

title.children: Decision not to light up Opera House for King Charles coronation was political, emails reveal

image.altText: A man of Asian appearance wears a suit and steps out of a luxury car as its door is held open by someone else.

items.synopsis: Kim Jong Un vows support for Russia during a summit that the US warns could lead to more munitions for Moscow's war in Ukraine.

title.children: North Korea's leader vows full support for Russia's 'just fight' after viewing launchpads with Putin

image.altText: A band of four young people in the 1980s sit together behind a purple backdrop.

items.synopsis: When former The Go-Betweens drummer Lindy Morrison took stock of her life, she decided it was time to turn up the volume.

title.children: After The Go-Betweens, Lindy Morrison changed careers. Now she's returning to her first love

image.altText: a person in an Akubra hat silhouetted against an Indigenous flag

items.synopsis: The debate over the creation of a Indigenous advisory body has burst into a cacophony of noise, misinformation, confusion and abuse. We've been here before, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: Above the noise, there's one Voice we could be listening to

image.altText: A group of people, fronted by a man talking and pointing upwards, outside the High Court.

items.synopsis: Qantas took a long-running battle with the Transport Workers' Union over sacked staff to the High Court, where the airline lost its appeal.

title.children: Qantas workers celebrate historic 'The Castle vibes' win after High Court ruled the airline illegally sacked staff

image.altText: A Qantas aircraft is seen on the tarmac through a circular window.

items.synopsis: Public servants from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and the Civil Aviation and Safety Authority have accepted membership to Qantas’ invite-only Chairman’s Lounge, while their agencies were responsible for regulating the airline.

title.children: Senior public servants responsible for regulating Qantas accepted Chairman’s Lounge invitations

image.altText: Kids and residents playing and swimming in the Olympic-size swimming pool

items.synopsis: Walgett's only pool closed indefinitely this year after the council was unable to find up to $2 million to repair it, with the mayor calling the situation an emergency.

title.children: Fears river drownings will spike as outback town prepares for scorching summer with no pool

image.altText: Smoke rises at a shipyard.

items.synopsis: At least 24 people have been injured after a missile attack on the Sevastopol Shipyard, the Russian-installed governor says.

title.children: Crimean shipyard on fire, two ships damaged in Ukrainian missile attack

image.altText: Graph depicting sea ice melting.

items.synopsis: Scientists say warming ocean temperatures are having an alarming impact on Antarctic sea ice levels, with currently 1.5 million square kilometres less sea ice than is typical at this time.

title.children: Sea ice freezes and melts with the seasons. But this year, it's looking a bit different

image.altText: Nick Kaldas addressing the National Press Club

items.synopsis: The chair of the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide takes the unusual step of addressing the National Press Club, insisting he did so because the inquiry is failing to gain enough attention in the media or with politicians.

title.children: 'The issues we've uncovered have not been noticed': Royal commissioner speaks out

image.altText: Law enforcement officers escort a prisoner.

items.synopsis: Convicted murderer Danelo Cavalcante had been on the run since August 31, when he escaped from Chester County Prison by climbing between two walls in the jail house yard and scrambling onto the roof.

title.children: 'Crab-walking' Pennsylvania prison escapee recaptured after two-week-long manhunt
